Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Nicholas Bradley Vrvilo of Rice University to conduct a research project, entitled "Preemptive work scheduling on a graphics processing unit," during the summer of 2012 at National Taiwan University in Taipei, Taiwan (ROC). The host scientist is Yang Chia-lin.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is manyfold. Targeting GPUs for preemptive work scheduling is a topic not extensively reported in the current literature. The concept of multiprogramming has traditionally focused on CPUs with a single thread of execution. By their parallel nature GPU architectures are already inherently multi-threaded, making them a less obvious target for multiprogramming. The complexities of memory management would also have hindered multiprogramming in the past, however, the additional memory options in the latest NVIDIA Fermi architecture allow for easier memory management in the GPU. These new features make it more feasible to suspend and resume computations without introducing an unacceptable amount of overhead because moving task data is not as complicated as it was with older GPU architectures.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of my time in the NSF EAPSI program this summer was spent doing research in the Embedded Computing Lab at National Taiwan University. Our work focused on improving virtualization technology for Graphics Processing Units (GPUs). After completion of the program we have continued our efforts to collaborate, and at this point are mainly focused on writing up our findings. We have already submitted one paper to a major conference, and have a second in the works. I presented the results of our work at a seminar at Rice University in October, and that has led to discussions about incorporating our findings into other NSF-funded projects here at Rice University.

            In addition to my research activities in Taiwan, my international experience there also included many cultural activities. Throughout the course of my time in Taiwan we visited several sacred religious sites, learning about traditional culture and beliefs. We enjoyed a variety of local cuisine and learned about food-related aspects of the culture. We learned about several local ethnic groups, visiting sites specifically dedicated to help us further understand Taiwanese Aboriginal people and the Hakka people—two minorities in Taiwan. I also had the opportunity to experience a traditional Taiwanese wedding, explore the National Palace Museum, view Chiang Kai-shek Memorial, and participate in many other activities that have helped to increase my international cultural and political awareness, and making me a more globally-engaged researcher.

            While at National Taiwan University we made several interesting discoveries furthering our efforts to provide efficient GPU virtualization technology. Our findings on the overhead associated with executing partial computation kernels on a GPU directly influenced the design of the resulting fairness-aware GPU time-slicing runtime. This runtime allows for easier sharing of limited GPU resources in supercomputing clusters among multiple researchers, and has impact on common GPU-accelerated applications in the fields of medical imaging, ray calculations, and many other simulations and computations. We are currently engaged in preparing and submitting the results of our research for publication and better public availability.

            The NSF EAPSI program provided me the unique opportunity to not only experience research in a different geographical and cultural context, but also strengthened the relationship between researchers on both sides of the Pacific. The NSF EAPSI program is invaluable in creating globally engaged researchers, effectively collaborating with international colleagues and the frontier of scientific knowledge worldwide.
